Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of a Sub-waivelength THz Spectral Imager for Photonic and Phononic Metamaterial and Devices Research at the Univesity of Arizona

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches:

The objective of this research is to design and construct a state-of-the-art terahertz near-field spectral imager. The approach is to combine recently developed computational sensing techniques and metamaterial-inspired electrically-small antenna technologies to achieve highly sub-wavelength imaging capabilities. This enhanced imaging capability will transform the current understanding of physical and biological processes as well as the engineering of terahertz devices and systems.

Intellectual Merit:

In contrast to existing commercially available terahertz instrumentation, the combination of advanced technologies will produce a terahertz near-field spectral imager with unprecedented signal-to-noise ratio and resolution.
Participating students, postdocs, and faculty will gain invaluable practical experience as the individual components are integrated over the course of the project into a functioning state-of-the-art system that is then used to explore cutting-edge applications in biology and materials. In addition, the resulting instrument lays the groundwork for further research of all types in the terahertz band.

Broader Impact:

The resulting instrument will be made available not only to local researchers, but also to the wider terahertz community including local industry and national and international collaborators. This will allow the instrument's unique capabilities to be brought to bear on a variety of terahertz research areas with high societal and economic impact, including spectroscopy of phononic nanostructures; investigations of passive and active metamaterials; and studies of biological processes in single cells. These opportunities will strongly encourage students, especially from underrepresented groups and ethnically diverse populations, for example, the Native American Tohono O'odham Nation, to participate.

The terahertz (THz) frequency range, from 100 to 10,000 GHz, lies between the microwave and the optical regimes. Most commercial cell phone systems and other wireless mobile platforms operate at microwave frequencies. On the other hand, what we see naturally occurs at optical frequencies, around 600,000 GHz. Until the 1980’s the THz frequency band was relatively unexplored. The initial explorations of material properties with THz systems were enabled by the development of ultrafast (femtosecond) laser systems, materials that convert these ultrashort laser pulses into THz signals, and the antennas that radiate them into free space. Since then, the so-called “THz Gap” has also been bridged with new technologies that use devices that upshift frequency signals from the microwave regime or devices that downshift frequency signals from the optical regime.

 

There is great interest in developing improved THz systems that can monitor the unique signatures or responses of molecules to THz signals. For example, THz frequencies provide us with a window to interrogate a material and distinguish the presence of highly energetic explosives or detrimental biological agents. Another interesting application arises from vibrations in materials being in the THz regime enabling us to probe and explore a material’s phononic (acoustic) structure. Moreover, because THz signals can be generated readily as time pulses, they can be used to determine both the properties and thicknesses of different layers of a multi-layered structure. This has important applications in manufacturing processes, e.g, in determining the uniformity of layers used in time-released drug capsules. Furthermore, unlike optical signals, THz signals can readily penetrate clothing. Consequently, there is great interest for THz-based security imaging systems with many people having already (perhaps unknowingly) experienced being scanned in a THz system by airport security. Combining the depth of penetration with biological signatures, THz beams are unique in their ability to examine and monitor skin cancers.

The NSF MRI project entitled the Development of a Sub-wavelength THz Spectral Imager for Photonic and Phononic Metamaterial and Devices Research at the University of Arizona (Award ID 1126572) has enabled our multidisciplinary team to construct a state-of-the-art Terahertz Spectral Imager and to fully characterize its operation. The latter includes optically stable tables and all of the appropriately aligned micrometer-tunable lenses, mirrors, etc. These components are required to focus the generated THz beam onto an object or sample, and then capture and measure the fields scattered from it. All of the originally proposed project goals were achieved. Antennas were successfully designed and a variety of substrates were tested to achieve the desired enhancement of the radiated THz power An array of these antennas was combined with computational sensing techniques to realize subwavelength resolution of a test fixture. At 100 GHz, the wavelength is 3 millimeters. We achieved the desired sub-wavelength resolution, about one-tenth of that wavelength (about 300 microns or about one hundredth of an inch) by combining the evanescent near-field multiplexed signals radiated by the array. Terahertz spectra of molecular and biological matter have been successfully measured with our new instrument to demonstrate the breadth of possible science projects. The state-of-the-art Terahertz Spectral Imager is installed in the University Spectroscopy and Imaging Facility (USIF) at The University of Arizona, a core multi-user facility on campus.
